column.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a tall solid upright stone post used to support a building or as a decoration
column.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a line of numbers or words written under each other that goes down a page
column.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Add up the numbers in each column.
column.translation[0].definitions[2].def: an article on a particular subject or by a particular writer that appears regularly in a newspaper or magazine
column.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: He writes a weekly column for ‘The Times’.
column.translation[0].definitions[3].def: one of two or more areas of print that go down the page of a newspaper or book and that are separated from each other by a narrow space
column.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: ‘The Sun’ devoted ten column inches to the event  (=their article filled a column ten inches long).
column.translation[0].definitions[4].def: something that has a tall thin shape
column.translation[0].definitions[5].def: a long moving line of people or things
column.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 3: an article on a particular subject or by a particular writer that appears regularly in a newspaper or magazine
column.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: He’s the writer of a weekly newspaper column.
Her daily column covered a wide range of topics.
His views were well-known from his regular column in The Spectator magazine.
She was upset by an item in the Washington Times gossip column.
He wrote a financial column for the evening newspaper.
Thousands of letters poured in to the correspondence column.
I spotted Stephenson's name in the obituary column.
I put a small advertisement in the personal column of the paper.
Romantic relationships are much discussed in all the agony columns.
Some men place advertisements in the lonely hearts columns.
He writes a column on gardening for the Daily News.
Lynch had a weekly column in a Sydney newspaper.
Many column inches have recently been devoted to the troubled pop star.
column.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a line of numbers written or printed under each other so that they can be easily added up, or a space on a page or on a computer screen for numbers to be arranged in this way
column.translation[1].definitions[1].def: one of two or more lines of print that go down the page of a newspaper or book and that are separated from each other by a narrow space
